description: Famous for being one of the smallest firearms ever made, the Kolibri pistol is a semi-automatic micro handgun designed in the Austro-Hungarian Empire on the eve of the first world war. It is perhaps fitting that its designer, Franz Pfannl, was a watchmaker, as a weapon of this liliputian scale could only be made with the precision and craft of such a precise artisan. Despite, or perhaps because of, the gun's odd nature and extremely anemic cartridge, it did not sell well at all and has since become a collector's item. Whether or not this weapon will have any use in the cataclysm is very much in doubt.
A standard capacity magazine for the 2mm kolibri micro-pistol.

A small, lightweight carbine designed for use with rear echelon support troops in the second world war after a lengthy and competitive design process. Lightweight, fairly accurate and with a passable (although somewhat anemic by later standards) cartridge, this variant is rather curious, essentially acting as a pared-down m1 with a pistol grip and a sawn-down barrel.

The Colt Woodsman is a semi-automatic sporting pistol manufactured by the U.S.Colt's Manufacturing Company from 1915 to 1977. It was designed by John Moses Browning. Browning developed the Woodsman with a short slide, no grip safety and no hammer.
A factory specification 10-round magazine for the Colt Woodsman.
A factory specification 10-round magazine for the Colt Woodsman. This variant is makeshift.

Designed by the Plainfield Machine Company of New Jersey, the Plainfield 71 is a simple blowback pistol whose purpose and origins are rather shrouded in mystery. Many ruminations have centered around this pistol, with little to show for it.
A factory specification 10-round magazine for the Plainsfield 71.

An iconic prototype firearm produced in very small numbers during the 1960s. Unlike the vast majority of firearms, the gyrojet family of weapons uses a small rocket propelled-projectile, with the lethality of its projectile being at maximum some distance after the muzzle. Due to the rocket-propelled projectile at the heart of the gyrojet system, gyrojet weapons could be made to be very lightweight on account of having little recoil, and very quiet as well. Despite their advanced features, the gyrojets were marred by development problems, anemic damage output at close range and general inaccuracy.

An iconic prototype firearm produced in very small numbers during the 1960s. Unlike the vast majority of firearms, the gyrojet family of weapons uses a small rocket propelled-projectile, with the lethality of its projectile being at maximum some distance after the muzzle. Due to the rocket-propelled projectile at the heart of the gyrojet system, gyrojet weapons could be made to be very lightweight on account of having little recoil, and very quiet as well. Despite their advanced features, the gyrojets were marred by development problems, anemic damage output at close range and general inaccuracy. This is a custom gyrojet variant, being slightly accurized and with a magazine well, in addition to accomodations for various mods.

A laser powered handgun initially made for Soviet Cosmonauts with the obscure purpose of blinding American sensors (and astronauts), this pistol was somehow given a new lease on life. Its power output has been drastically increased to the point where the laser beam can actually inflict grievous harm on others, while still retaining some ability to stun targets.

The first commercially successful revolver ever made, the Colt Paterson ushered in a new epoch in firearms design that codified small arms for the better part of eighty years after its initial conception. Made by the famed engineer Samuel Colt and used by soldiers of the Republic of Texas, United States and Confederate States of America. Despite being a nearly two hundred year old design, it is still fairly accurate, albeit somewhat difficult to reload. This is a later variant, and as such features a reloading lever in addition to the cylinder capable of being removed.
This cylinder can hold 5 rounds of .36 caliber cap and ball to use with the Paterson.
A custom magazine containing six rounds of 13mm gyrojet ammunition.
A factory specification 10-round magazine for the Plainsfield 71.
A factory specification 10-round magazine for the Plainsfield 71.

//: You can get 'em for over US$1K if you want.  This is a fairly cheap remake.
description: A prototype single-shot breech loading pistol chambered for .50 BMG, of all things. The huge muzzle brake provides a semblance of recoil reduction (along with a recoil reduction system), but this pistol's recoil will be punishing in any event.

Designed as a desperate measure for the volkssturm in the last days of the third reich, the Mauser HSc was one of several volkspistole (people's gun) made with the priority of ease of production above all else. Little more than a barrel, folded sheet metal and rivets, the Mauser HSc is an 8-shot 9mm pistol that was made in very small numbers. How it wound up in New England as either a genuine article or a reproduction is beyond understanding.
An 8 round steel box magazine for the Mauser HSc. Simple enough to be homemade
The Danuvia VD.01 is a prototype machine pistol designed by Robert Voros in 1989. It uses a simple blowback system and a unique helical magazine storing 33 rounds.
A surprisingly compact 33-round helical magazine for use with the Calico Danuvia VD.01.
the FK BRNO field pistol is a semi-automatic firearm designed to use the proprietary high-velocity 7.5 FK round. This pistol is optimized for high muzzle velocity, accuracy and terminal performance.
A standard capacity magazine for use with the FK BRNO field pistol.
A nakeshift magazine for use with the FK BRNO field pistol.

A 15 round pistol that is essentially a hybrid between a magazine-fed pistol and a revolver. The gun uses cartridges known as 'trounds', essentially .38 or .22 caliber pistol cartridges wrapped by a triangular plastic casing that extends to the tip of the bullet. These pistols were developed by the engineer Richard Dardick and saw little popularity on account of their expensive price, odd ammo and generally ungainly dimensions.

A prototype revolver developed by the Soviet Union, the TOZ-81 is a unique designed to reflect the equally unique needs of its intended operator: cosmonauts. Chambered for the 5.45x39mm cartridge, the TOZ-81 was desigend for use by downed cosmonauts to help them fend for themselves in the hostile wilderness that dominate large parts of the expanse that was the Soviet Union. Unlike most revolvers, the TOZ-81's barrel is situated beneath the bottom cylinder rather than the top. Although unique, the TOZ-81 failed to receive approval from the Soviet Government.
